   Assessment and Plan
   40M with recent h/o tumor lysis syndrome, started chemotherapy on [**7-21**]
   for Burkitt
s lymphoma. New diagnosis of acromegaly, in ICU with
   respiratory failure in setting of pneumonia, possible ARDS. Original
   presenting complaint was Bell
s Palsy, urinary retention, and lower
   extremity weakness.
   Respiratory failure: intubated since [**7-12**], one failed extubation on [**7-15**]
   secondary to copious secretions. Intermittent dysynchrony with vent,
   PSV has increased his comfort level.  Contributing factors to
   respiratory status include PNA and suspicion for infiltrative malignant
   process on CT, as well as meeting ARDS criteria starting [**7-18**]. However,
   compliance has remained normal so tolerating large tidal volumes on
   PSV.
   -Continue PSV, wean pressures as tolerated. Goal is ph>7.20, C02<70.
   -Daily breathing trials while on PSV, follow RISB when weaned toward
   [**5-19**]. (RISB today 15 on PSV 10/10, Vt 800, Rate 12)
   -Sedation with fentanyl/midazolam
   -Continue diuresis to at least 100-200cc/hr as it is improving his
   respiratory status and as his Na level tolerates
   -follow ABGs when changes in ventilator settings or respiratory status
   -Daily CXR
   Pneumonia/Infection: ongoing fevers with persistent infiltrates at R
   base on CXR. WBC elevated on [**7-18**], now precipitously dropped in setting
   of chemotherapy. Patient is now neutropenic (ANC<<500)
   -Vanco and meropenem d/c
ed yesterday (10 days vanco, 3 days [**Last Name (un) **]
   total)
   -cipro (day 6,start [**7-19**])
   -cefepime 2gm IV q8h (day 2)
   -flagyl 500mg IV TID (day 2)
   -doxycycline 100mg [**Hospital1 **] for mycoplasma coverage (day 3)
   -fluconazole for ppx  (day 4, start [**7-21**])
   -Start acyclovir for ppx (day 3)
   -Bactrim d/c
ed, continue atovaquone for PCP [**Name Initial (PRE) 1694**] (day 2)
   -check G6PD for above, if negative, switch to dapsone
   -urine cx for Mycoplasma hominsis pending
   -f/u final BAL results, blood cx, CSF fungal, AFB, and viral cx, CSF
   EBV PCR, serum EBV, CMV, HHV-6 PCR, and galactomannan and B-glucan
   Tumor lysis syndrome: Labs at admission were significant for elevated
   LDH, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia which all resolved
   to baseline. Patient s/p 2 doses rasburicase. Tumor lysis labs started
   to rise again on [**7-21**]. Today they are trending down.
   -f/u tumor lysis labs Q6H
   -keep UOP at least 100cc/hr with lasix gtt and HC03 IVF as long as
   Na<150
   -s/p 3^rd dose rasburicase
   -continue allopurinol
   -low phos tube feeds
   -started aluminum hydroxide for PO phos binding
   -continue kaexelate
   -renal consult in setting of worsening lab values with distinct
   possibility of needing dialysis (CVVHD?) in near future
   Burkitt
s lymphoma: CT shows diffuse evidence of malignancy - c/w
   lymphangitic spread of diffuse malignant process, thickening in
   stomach, ureters. Bone marrow bx c/w Burkitt
s lymphoma. Hyper-CVAD
   started on [**7-21**]. now s/p [**3-20**] doses cyclophosphamide, cytarabine
   intrathecal x 1, m
   -f/u onc recs
   -consult rad-onc for possibility of radiation to skull in light of
   cranial nerve palsies. Likely will need imaging first.
   -intrathecal methotrexate today
   -dexamethasone daily 40mg
   Pancytopenia: Platelets following throughout this admission,
   precipitous drop in WBC on day 1 of chemo, Hct in low 20s throughout
   most of admission.
   -s/p 3 units of PRBCs over last 48 hours
   -give platelets if needed
   -CBC Q8H
   -start neupogen today
   -neutropenic precautions
   Tachycardia: Consistently tachycardic to 110s/120s. TSH WNL, TTE showed
   normal EF and no evidence of heart failure. Repeat EKGs have shown
   frequent PVCs, no signs of myocardial ischemia. Likely physiologic
   tachycardia secondary to infection, lymphoma, anemia, high [**Hospital1 **].
   -maximize comfort on ventilator
   -EKG from [**7-23**] at baseline
   -continue metoprolol 50mg Q6H
   Distended abdomen: abdominal distention is stable with hypoactive bowel
   sounds. No stool for 4 days.
   -Colace increased, receiving senna, dulcolax, and lactulose
   -s/p methylnaltrexone x1. repeat if no stool in 24h
   -Try to wean fentanyl as possible
   Social:
   -social work consulted
   -family meeting today (endocrine available between 12 and 2pm), contact
   family to ensure their presence and request onc
s presence as well
   The following issues are not acute or active but left on the note to be
   followed up on when Mr. [**Known lastname 7019**] is awake and stabilized:
   Acromegaly: New presumptive diagnosis based on clinical features.
   Definitive work-up postponed until patient stabilized.
   -f/u with endocrine
   -f/u endocrine labs (IGFBP, Vit D)
   -ophtho consult for visual fields when patient extubated/alert
   Orchitis:  Tender scrotal swelling on admission, scrotal US suggested
   epididymitis/orchitis. No clear masses. G&C swab negative. Exam
   starting [**7-17**] shows marked increase in testicular swelling, particularly
   on the left. Thought to be secondary to malignant infiltration and
   generalized edema.
   -f/u when patient stabilized, likely due to lymphoma
   Neurologic abnormalities: Initial patient complaints included R Bell
   palsy, loss of R facial sensation, weakness/decreased sensation of
   lower extremities. MRI T-spine at OSH showed epidural enhancement of
   thoracic spine; MRI head showed pituitary macroadenoma.
   -neurosurgery has low suspicion for cord compression and repeat MRI of
   spine not necessary.
   -Repeat MRI of pituitary eventually needed although in light of recent
   ARF, this is not a priority and can wait until patient stabilized.
   -better neuro exam as we wean sedation, particularly focused on cranial
   nerve
s V and VII and lower extremity sensation/motor
   Joint pain: Patient has severe and diffuse arthralgias, most likely

   -avoiding NSAIDs
   -tylenol when awake

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 40-year-old male with a complex medical history, including Burkitt's lymphoma, acromegaly, pneumonia, and possible ARDS. The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with PSV 10/10, high tidal volumes, and a FiO2 of 50%. He has a history of tumor lysis syndrome, which has been managed with rasburicase and allopurinol.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is closely monitored, and the physician is considering weaning the ventilator. However, the patient's underlying condition, including pneumonia and possible ARDS, may continue to compromise his respiratory function.
2. Infection: The patient has ongoing fevers and persistent infiltrates on his CXR, which may indicate a continued risk of infection. The physician is monitoring his WBC count, which has precipitously dropped in response to chemotherapy.
3. Tumor lysis syndrome: The patient's tumor lysis labs are trending down, but the physician is continuing to monitor them closely to ensure that the patient does not develop hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, or hyperuricemia again.
4. Pancytopenia: The patient has a history of pancytopenia, which may continue to pose a risk of bleeding or infection. The physician is monitoring his platelet count and is considering transfusions if necessary.
5. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia is likely due to infection, lymphoma, anemia, and high levels of catecholamines. The physician is monitoring his EKGs and is considering adjusting his medication regimen to manage his tachycardia.
6. Distended abdomen: The patient's abdominal distention is stable, but the physician is monitoring his bowel sounds and is considering increasing his stool softeners and laxatives to manage his constipation.
7. Neurological abnormalities: The patient has a history of Bell's palsy, loss of facial sensation, and weakness in his lower extremities. The physician is monitoring his neurological status and is considering repeat MRI studies to evaluate his pituitary gland and spine.
8. Acromegaly: The patient has a presumptive diagnosis of acromegaly, which may require further evaluation and management.

In terms of the patient's current medications, he is receiving a variety of medications to manage his respiratory failure, infection, and tumor lysis syndrome, including fentanyl, midazolam, vancomycin, meropenem, ciprofloxacin, and doxycycline. He is also receiving medications to manage his pancytopenia, including platelet transfusions and neutropenic precautions.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 40-year-old male with a complex medical history, including recent diagnoses of Burkitt's lymphoma, acromegaly, and tumor lysis syndrome. He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation for respiratory failure, likely due to pneumonia and possible ARDS.

The patient has undergone several rounds of chemotherapy, including Hyper-CVAD, and has received multiple antibiotics for suspected infections. He has also been treated for tumor lysis syndrome with rasburicase and allopurinol.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of pancytopenia, with low white blood cell count, platelet count, and hemoglobin levels. He has also had a precipitous drop in his WBC count following chemotherapy.

The patient's physical examination reveals acromegalic features, including frontal bossing, large jaw, and coarse facial features. He has also developed marked testicular swelling, which is thought to be secondary to malignant infiltration and generalized edema.

Potential medical complications that may arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status may continue to deteriorate due to pneumonia and possible ARDS, requiring further interventions such as increased ventilator support or consideration of extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
2. Infection: The patient's neutropenic state and ongoing fevers increase the risk of infection, which may require additional antibiotics and/or antifungals.
3. Tumor lysis syndrome: The patient's laboratory results show evidence of tumor lysis syndrome, which may require further treatment with rasburicase and allopurinol.
4. Pancytopenia: The patient's low white blood cell count, platelet count, and hemoglobin levels increase the risk of bleeding, infection, and other complications.
5. Acromegaly: The patient's acromegalic features may require further evaluation and treatment, including hormone replacement therapy and surgical intervention.
6. Orchitis: The patient's testicular swelling may require further evaluation and treatment, including antibiotics and/or surgical drainage.
7. Neurological complications: The patient's neurological symptoms, including Bell's palsy and lower extremity weakness, may require further evaluation and treatment, including physical therapy and possible surgical intervention.
8. Joint pain: The patient's severe and diffuse arthralgias may require further evaluation and treatment, including pain management and possible joint injections.

In summary, the patient's complex medical condition requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential complications. Further evaluation and treatment may be necessary to address his acromegaly, orchitis, and neurological symptoms.

Summary:

The patient is a 69-year-old male with a diagnosis of lymphoma, currently admitted to the ICU for acute respiratory failure, acute renal failure, and sepsis. The patient has been receiving multiple antibiotics and medications, including vancomycin, bactrim, meropenem, acyclovir, doxycycline, fluconazole, metronidazole, and ciprofloxacin. The patient has been transfused with 3 units of blood and is receiving intrathecal corticosteroids. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 38C, heart rate of 100 bpm, and blood pressure of 112/56 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, creatinine, and lactate dehydrogenase, indicating possible sepsis and renal failure. The patient's electrolyte levels are also abnormal, with hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia, and hyperphosphatemia.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's laboratory results suggest sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ dysfunction, including respiratory failure, acute kidney injury, and cardiovascular instability.
2. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): The patient's respiratory failure and hypoxemia may progress to ARDS, which can lead to respiratory failure and mortality.
3. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's elevated creatinine and lactate dehydrogenase levels suggest AKI, which can lead to electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and cardiovascular instability.
4. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's tachycardia and hypotension may indicate cardiovascular instability, which can lead to cardiac arrest and mortality.
5. Skin integrity issues: The patient's impaired skin integrity may lead to pressure ulcers, infections, and prolonged hospitalization.
6. Malnutrition: The patient's poor nutritional status may exacerbate his underlying medical conditions and increase the risk of complications.
7. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's abnormal electrolyte levels may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and neurological deficits.
8. Infection: The patient's sepsis and impaired skin integrity may increase the risk of infection, which can lead to septic shock and mortality.

   Assessment and Plan
   40M with recent h/o tumor lysis syndrome, started chemotherapy on [**7-21**]
   for Burkitt
s lymphoma. New diagnosis of acromegaly, in ICU with
   respiratory failure in setting of pneumonia, possible ARDS. Original
   presenting complaint was Bell
s Palsy, urinary retention, and lower
   extremity weakness.
   Respiratory failure: intubated since [**7-12**], one failed extubation on [**7-15**]
   secondary to copious secretions. Intermittent dysynchrony with vent,
   PSV has increased his comfort level.  Contributing factors to
   respiratory status include PNA and suspicion for infiltrative malignant
   process on CT, as well as meeting ARDS criteria starting [**7-18**]. However,
   compliance has remained normal so tolerating large tidal volumes on
   PSV.
   -Continue PSV, wean pressures as tolerated to [**5-19**] today.
   -Breathing trial today, follow RISB when weaned toward [**5-19**]. (RISB today
   15 on PSV 10/10, Vt 800, Rate 12)
   -Wean sedation with fentanyl/midazolam
   -Continue diuresis to at least 100-200cc/hr as it is improving his
   respiratory status and as his Na level tolerates
   -follow ABGs when changes in ventilator settings or respiratory status
   (Goal is ph>7.20, C02<70)
   -Daily CXR
   Pneumonia/Infection: ongoing fevers with persistent infiltrates at R
   base on CXR. WBC elevated on [**7-18**], now precipitously dropped in setting
   of chemotherapy. Patient is now neutropenic (ANC<<500)
   -Vanco and meropenem d/c
ed yesterday (10 days vanco, 3 days [**Last Name (un) **]
   total)
   -cipro (day 6,start [**7-19**])
   -cefepime 2gm IV q8h (day 2)
   -flagyl 500mg IV TID (day 2)
   -touch base with ID regarding stopping flagyl today, cipro tomorrow to
   increase number of abx
   -doxycycline 100mg [**Hospital1 **] for mycoplasma coverage (day 3)
   -fluconazole for ppx  (day 4, start [**7-21**])
   -Start acyclovir for ppx (day 3)
   -Bactrim d/c
ed, continue atovaquone for PCP [**Name Initial (PRE) 1694**] (day 2)
   -check G6PD for above, if negative, switch to dapsone
   -urine cx for Mycoplasma hominsis pending
   -f/u final BAL results, blood cx, CSF fungal, AFB, and viral cx, CSF
   EBV PCR, serum EBV, CMV, HHV-6 PCR, and galactomannan and B-glucan
   Tumor lysis syndrome: Labs at admission were significant for elevated
   LDH, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia which all resolved
   to baseline. Patient s/p 2 doses rasburicase. Tumor lysis labs started
   to rise again on [**7-21**]. Today they are trending down.
   -f/u tumor lysis labs Q8H
   -keep UOP at least 100cc/hr with lasix gtt
   -check urine pH tomorrow
   -stop HC03 as respiratory status better with less IVF and tumor lysis
   labs stable (could consider oral HC03)
   -s/p 3^rd dose rasburicase
   -continue allopurinol
   -low phos tube feeds
   -aluminum hydroxide for PO phos binding
   -continue kaexelate
   -f/u renal recs
   Burkitt
s lymphoma: CT shows diffuse evidence of malignancy - c/w
   lymphangitic spread of diffuse malignant process, thickening in
   stomach, ureters. Bone marrow bx c/w Burkitt
s lymphoma. Hyper-CVAD
   started on [**7-21**]. now s/p [**3-20**] doses cyclophosphamide, cytarabine
   intrathecal x 1, m
   -f/u onc recs
   -vincristine and doxorubicin today
   -consult rad-onc for possibility of radiation to skull in light of
   cranial nerve palsies. Likely will need imaging first. (Hold off on
   this for now)
   -intrathecal methotrexate today
   -dexamethasone daily 40mg
   Pancytopenia: Platelets following throughout this admission,
   precipitous drop in WBC on day 1 of chemo, Hct in low 20s throughout
   most of admission.
   -s/p 3 units of PRBCs over last 48 hours
   -transfuse again if needed (Hct<21)
   -give platelets if needed (<15)
   -CBC Q8H
   -start neupogen today
   -neutropenic precautions
   Tachycardia: Consistently tachycardic to 110s/120s. TSH WNL, TTE showed
   normal EF and no evidence of heart failure. Repeat EKGs have shown
   frequent PVCs, no signs of myocardial ischemia. Likely physiologic
   tachycardia secondary to infection, lymphoma, anemia, high [**Hospital1 **].
   -maximize comfort on ventilator
   -EKG on [**7-23**] at baseline
   -continue metoprolol 50mg Q6H
   Distended abdomen: abdominal distention is stable with hypoactive bowel
   sounds. No stool for 4 days.
   -Colace increased, receiving senna, dulcolax, and lactulose
   -s/p methylnaltrexone x1. repeat if no stool in 24h
   -Try to wean fentanyl as possible
   -add PO narcan
   Hyperglycemia: blood glucose in the 200s starting [**7-23**]. likely largely
   due to the dexamethasone.
   -increase ISS. If persists in the 200s add insulin drip.
   Social:
   -social work consulted
   -family meeting today for providing more information about diagnoses
   The following issues are not acute or active but left on the note to be
   followed up on when Mr. [**Known lastname 7019**] is awake and stabilized:
   Acromegaly: New presumptive diagnosis based on clinical features.
   Definitive work-up postponed until patient stabilized.
   -f/u with endocrine
   -f/u endocrine labs (IGFBP, Vit D)
   -ophtho consult for visual fields when patient extubated/alert
   Orchitis:  Tender scrotal swelling on admission, scrotal US suggested
   epididymitis/orchitis. No clear masses. G&C swab negative. Exam
   starting [**7-17**] shows marked increase in testicular swelling, particularly
   on the left. Thought to be secondary to malignant infiltration and
   generalized edema.
   -f/u when patient stabilized, likely due to lymphoma
   Neurologic abnormalities: Initial patient complaints included R Bell
   palsy, loss of R facial sensation, weakness/decreased sensation of
   lower extremities. MRI T-spine at OSH showed epidural enhancement of
   thoracic spine; MRI head showed pituitary macroadenoma.
   -neurosurgery has low suspicion for cord compression and repeat MRI of
   spine not necessary.
   -Repeat MRI of pituitary eventually needed although in light of recent
   ARF, this is not a priority and can wait until patient stabilized.
   -better neuro exam as we wean sedation, particularly focused on cranial
   nerve
s V and VII and lower extremity sensation/motor
   Joint pain: Patient has severe and diffuse arthralgias, most likely
   secondary to hypertrophic arthropathy from acromegaly.
   -avoiding NSAIDs
   -tylenol when awake
   -continue pain control with fentanyl

Summary:

The patient is a 40-year-old male with a recent diagnosis of Burkitt's lymphoma, acromegaly, and tumor lysis syndrome. He was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure due to pneumonia and possible ARDS. He has been intubated since day 12 and has had two failed extubation attempts. He is currently receiving chemotherapy, including hyper-CVAD, and has received three doses of rasburicase to manage tumor lysis syndrome.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory: Intubated, receiving PSV 10/10 with high tidal volumes, and tolerating large tidal volumes.
* Cardiovascular: Tachycardic, with a heart rate of 100-117 bpm, and normal cardiac function.
* Neurological: Alert and oriented, with no cranial nerve palsies appreciated.
* Renal: Receiving diuresis with lasix, and his sodium level is currently 148 mmol/L.
* Hematological: Neutropenic, with an ANC of <500.
* Infection: Ongoing fevers with persistent infiltrates on CXR, and a positive EBV PCR result.
* Pain: Receiving pain control with fentanyl and other medications.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is currently stable, but he may continue to require intubation and mechanical ventilation.
2. Infection: The patient has ongoing fevers and persistent infiltrates on CXR, which may indicate a worsening infection.
3. Tumor lysis syndrome: The patient's tumor lysis syndrome is currently stable, but it may continue to worsen if not managed properly.
4. Neutropenia: The patient is currently neutropenic, which may increase his risk of infection.
5. Acromegaly: The patient's acromegaly may continue to worsen if not managed properly, which may lead to further complications.
6. Pancytopenia: The patient's pancytopenia may continue to worsen if not managed properly, which may increase his risk of infection and bleeding.
7. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia may continue to worsen if not managed properly, which may lead to further complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his ventilator settings as needed.
2. Continue to manage his infection with antibiotics and other medications.
3. Continue to manage his tumor lysis syndrome with rasburicase and other medications.
4. Continue to monitor his neutrophil count and adjust his treatment plan as needed.
5. Continue to manage his acromegaly with medications and other therapies.
6. Continue to monitor his pancytopenia and adjust his treatment plan as needed.
7. Continue to manage his hyperglycemia with insulin and other medications.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 69-inch tall, 93 kg male who was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of lymphoma and acute respiratory failure. He was intubated and receiving invasive ventilation, but was extubated and reintubated due to hypercapnic respiratory distress. The patient has been experiencing fever, tachycardia, and hypotension, and has been receiving various medications including antibiotics, antifungals, and steroids. He has also been receiving insulin drip for hyperglycemia and has been monitored for potential complications such as sepsis, ARDS, and DVT.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever, tachycardia, and hypotension may indicate sepsis, which is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate attention.
2. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): The patient's respiratory failure and need for reintubation may indicate the development of ARDS, which can be a serious and potentially life-threatening condition.
3. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient's immobilization and underlying medical conditions may increase his risk of developing DVT, which can be a serious and potentially life-threatening condition.
4. Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure may require further evaluation and treatment to prevent complications such as electrolyte imbalances and acidosis.
5. Hypertension: The patient's hypotension may require further evaluation and treatment to prevent complications such as organ dysfunction and shock.
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia may require further evaluation and treatment to prevent complications such as ketoacidosis and hyperosmolar nonketotic syndrome.
7. Infection: The patient's fever and respiratory failure may indicate the presence of an underlying infection, which requires further evaluation and treatment.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's impaired skin integrity, fever, and hypotension require further evaluation and treatment. The patient's respiratory failure and need for reintubation require close monitoring and potential adjustment of his ventilation settings. The patient's acute renal failure requires further evaluation and treatment to prevent complications. The patient's hyperglycemia requires further evaluation and treatment to prevent complications. The patient's lymphoma requires ongoing treatment and monitoring to prevent complications.

   40M with recent h/o tumor lysis syndrome, started chemotherapy on [**7-21**]
   for Burkitt
s lymphoma. New diagnosis of acromegaly, in ICU with
   respiratory failure in setting of pneumonia, possible ARDS. Original
   presenting complaint was Bell
s Palsy, urinary retention, and lower
   extremity weakness.
   Respiratory failure: intubated since [**7-12**], one failed extubation on [**7-15**]
   secondary to copious secretions. Intermittent dysynchrony with vent,
   PSV has increased his comfort level.  Contributing factors to
   respiratory status include PNA and suspicion for infiltrative malignant
   process on CT, as well as meeting ARDS criteria starting [**7-18**]. However,
   compliance has remained normal so tolerating large tidal volumes on
   PSV.
   -Continue PSV, wean pressures as tolerated to [**5-19**] today.
   -Breathing trial today, follow RISB when weaned toward [**5-19**]. (RISB today
   15 on PSV 10/10, Vt 800, Rate 12)
   -Wean sedation with fentanyl/midazolam
   -Continue diuresis to at least 100-200cc/hr as it is improving his
   respiratory status and as his Na level tolerates
   -follow ABGs when changes in ventilator settings or respiratory status
   (Goal is ph>7.20, C02<70)
   -Daily CXR
   Pneumonia/Infection: ongoing fevers with persistent infiltrates at R
   base on CXR. WBC elevated on [**7-18**], now precipitously dropped in setting
   of chemotherapy. Patient is now neutropenic (ANC<<500)
   -Vanco and meropenem d/c
ed yesterday (10 days vanco, 3 days [**Last Name (un) **]
   total)
   -cipro (day 6,start [**7-19**])
   -cefepime 2gm IV q8h (day 2)
   -flagyl 500mg IV TID (day 2)
   -touch base with ID regarding stopping flagyl today, cipro tomorrow to
   increase number of abx
   -doxycycline 100mg [**Hospital1 **] for mycoplasma coverage (day 3)
   -fluconazole for ppx  (day 4, start [**7-21**])
   -Start acyclovir for ppx (day 3)
   -Bactrim d/c
ed, continue atovaquone for PCP [**Name Initial (PRE) 1694**] (day 2)
   -check G6PD for above, if negative, switch to dapsone
   -urine cx for Mycoplasma hominsis pending
   -f/u final BAL results, blood cx, CSF fungal, AFB, and viral cx, CSF
   EBV PCR, serum EBV, CMV, HHV-6 PCR, and galactomannan and B-glucan
   Tumor lysis syndrome: Labs at admission were significant for elevated
   LDH, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia which all resolved
   to baseline. Patient s/p 2 doses rasburicase. Tumor lysis labs started
   to rise again on [**7-21**]. Today they are trending down.
   -f/u tumor lysis labs Q8H
   -keep UOP at least 100cc/hr with lasix gtt
   -check urine pH tomorrow
   -stop HC03 as respiratory status better with less IVF and tumor lysis
   labs stable (could consider oral HC03)
   -s/p 3^rd dose rasburicase
   -continue allopurinol
   -low phos tube feeds
   -aluminum hydroxide for PO phos binding
   -continue kaexelate
   -f/u renal recs
   Burkitt
s lymphoma: CT shows diffuse evidence of malignancy - c/w
   lymphangitic spread of diffuse malignant process, thickening in
   stomach, ureters. Bone marrow bx c/w Burkitt
s lymphoma. Hyper-CVAD
   started on [**7-21**]. now s/p [**3-20**] doses cyclophosphamide, cytarabine
   intrathecal x 1, m
   -f/u onc recs
   -vincristine and doxorubicin today
   -consult rad-onc for possibility of radiation to skull in light of
   cranial nerve palsies. Likely will need imaging first. (Hold off on
   this for now)
   -intrathecal methotrexate today
   -dexamethasone daily 40mg
   Pancytopenia: Platelets following throughout this admission,
   precipitous drop in WBC on day 1 of chemo, Hct in low 20s throughout
   most of admission.
   -s/p 3 units of PRBCs over last 48 hours
   -transfuse again if needed (Hct<21)
   -give platelets if needed (<15)
   -CBC Q8H
   -start neupogen today
   -neutropenic precautions
   Tachycardia: Consistently tachycardic to 110s/120s. TSH WNL, TTE showed
   normal EF and no evidence of heart failure. Repeat EKGs have shown
   frequent PVCs, no signs of myocardial ischemia. Likely physiologic
   tachycardia secondary to infection, lymphoma, anemia, high [**Hospital1 **].
   -maximize comfort on ventilator
   -EKG on [**7-23**] at baseline
   -continue metoprolol 50mg Q6H
   Distended abdomen: abdominal distention is stable with hypoactive bowel
   sounds. No stool for 4 days.
   -Colace increased, receiving senna, dulcolax, and lactulose
   -s/p methylnaltrexone x1. repeat if no stool in 24h
   -Try to wean fentanyl as possible
   -add PO narcan
   Hyperglycemia: blood glucose in the 200s starting [**7-23**]. likely largely
   due to the dexamethasone.
   -increase ISS. If persists in the 200s add insulin drip.
   Social:
   -social work consulted
   -family meeting today for providing more information about diagnoses
   The following issues are not acute or active but left on the note to be
   followed up on when Mr. [**Known lastname 7019**] is awake and stabilized:
   Acromegaly: New presumptive diagnosis based on clinical features.
   Definitive work-up postponed until patient stabilized.
   -f/u with endocrine
   -f/u endocrine labs (IGFBP, Vit D)
   -ophtho consult for visual fields when patient extubated/alert
   Orchitis:  Tender scrotal swelling on admission, scrotal US suggested
   epididymitis/orchitis. No clear masses. G&C swab negative. Exam
   starting [**7-17**] shows marked increase in testicular swelling, particularly
   on the left. Thought to be secondary to malignant infiltration and
   generalized edema.
   -f/u when patient stabilized, likely due to lymphoma
   Neurologic abnormalities: Initial patient complaints included R Bell
   palsy, loss of R facial sensation, weakness/decreased sensation of
   lower extremities. MRI T-spine at OSH showed epidural enhancement of
   thoracic spine; MRI head showed pituitary macroadenoma.
   -neurosurgery has low suspicion for cord compression and repeat MRI of
   spine not necessary.
   -Repeat MRI of pituitary eventually needed although in light of recent
   ARF, this is not a priority and can wait until patient stabilized.
   -better neuro exam as we wean sedation, particularly focused on cranial
   nerve
s V and VII and lower extremity sensation/motor
   Joint pain: Patient has severe and diffuse arthralgias, most likely
   secondary to hypertrophic arthropathy from acromegaly.
   -avoiding NSAIDs
   -tylenol when awake
   -continue pain control with fentanyl

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications are identified:

Summary:

The patient is a 40-year-old male with a recent history of tumor lysis syndrome, Burkitt's lymphoma, and acromegaly. He was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, pneumonia, and possible ARDS. He has undergone chemotherapy and has been intubated since admission. The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: intubated and on PSV, weaning pressures as tolerated
* Fever: 101.5F (38.6C)
* Hypotension: not in shock, but with a BP of 112/64 mmHg
* Renal failure: acute, with a creatinine of 0.6 mg/dL
* Lymphoma: Burkitt's lymphoma, with diffuse evidence of malignancy on CT
* Tumor lysis syndrome: labs trending down, but still elevated
* Pancytopenia: platelets low, WBC count precipitously dropped
* Tachycardia: consistently tachycardic to 110s/120s
* Distended abdomen: hypoactive bowel sounds, no stool for 4 days
* Hyperglycemia: blood glucose in the 200s
* Neurological abnormalities: R Bell palsy, loss of R facial sensation, weakness/decreased sensation of lower extremities
* Joint pain: severe and diffuse arthralgias

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he requires close monitoring and weaning of ventilator settings to prevent further complications.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever and elevated WBC count suggest the possibility of sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
3. Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure is a concern, and close monitoring of his creatinine levels and urine output is necessary to prevent further deterioration.
4. Tumor lysis syndrome: The patient's labs are still elevated, and close monitoring is necessary to prevent further complications.
5. Pancytopenia: The patient's low platelet count and WBC count make him prone to bleeding and infection, respectively.
6. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia is likely secondary to infection, lymphoma, anemia, and high cortisol levels, and close monitoring is necessary to prevent further complications.
7. Distended abdomen: The patient's hypoactive bowel sounds and lack of stool for 4 days suggest the possibility of bowel obstruction or perforation, which could lead to further complications.
8. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia is a concern, and close monitoring of his blood glucose levels and insulin drip is necessary to prevent further complications.
9. Neurological abnormalities: The patient's neurological abnormalities, including R Bell palsy and loss of R facial sensation, are a concern and require close monitoring and follow-up.
10. Joint pain: The patient's severe and diffuse arthralgias are likely secondary to hypertrophic arthropathy from acromegaly, and close monitoring is necessary to prevent further complications.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent further deterioration and improve his outcome.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Hyperglycemia management
* Pain management
* Distended abdomen management
* Orchitis management
* Neurologic abnormalities management

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure due to pneumonia or ARDS
* Tumor lysis syndrome worsening
* Pancytopenia leading to bleeding or infection
* Hyperglycemia leading to ketoacidosis or hyperosmolar nonketotic coma
* Distended abdomen leading to bowel obstruction or perforation
* Orchitis leading to testicular torsion or abscess
* Neurologic abnormalities leading to further decline in cognitive function or paralysis

The patient's ICU care plan includes:

* Close monitoring of vital signs and laboratory results
* Ventilatory support as needed
* Antibiotics for pneumonia
* Chemotherapy for Burkitt's lymphoma
* Tumor lysis syndrome treatment
* Hyperglycemia management
* Pain management
* Distended abdomen management
* Orchitis management
* Neurologic abnormalities management

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is pending further evaluation and treatment.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 40-year-old male with a recent diagnosis of Burkitt's lymphoma, acromegaly, and respiratory failure due to pneumonia and possible ARDS. The patient has been in the ICU for several days and has been intubated since day 7.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL. The patient is comfortable on the ventilator, and the goal is to wean FiO2 and PEEP as tolerated.
* Cardiovascular: The patient's blood pressure is 112/64 mmHg, and the heart rate is 94 bpm. The patient has a history of tachycardia, but it is likely physiologic due to infection, lymphoma, anemia, and high cortisol levels.
* Neurological: The patient has a history of Bell's palsy, loss of right facial sensation, and weakness/decreased sensation of lower extremities. The patient also has a pituitary macroadenoma and epidural enhancement of the thoracic spine on MRI.
* Renal: The patient has acute kidney injury, and the creatinine level is 0.6 mg/dL. The patient is receiving dialysis, and the goal is to maintain a creatinine level < 1.2 mg/dL.
* Infectious: The patient has a fever of 101.5F, and the WBC count is 0.3 K/L. The patient is neutropenic and is receiving antibiotics.
* Metabolic: The patient has hyperglycemia, and the blood glucose level is 275 mg/dL. The patient is receiving insulin drip, and the goal is to maintain a blood glucose level of 100-150 mg/dL.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has a distended abdomen, hypoactive bowel sounds, and no stool for 5 days. The patient is receiving lactulose and metronidazole.
* Hematological: The patient has pancytopenia, and the platelet count is 34 K/L. The patient is receiving platelet transfusions, and the goal is to maintain a platelet count > 15 K/L.
* Endocrine: The patient has acromegaly, and the patient is receiving treatment with a somatostatin analog.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is already intubated, and the risk of respiratory failure is high.
* Sepsis: The patient has a fever and is neutropenic, which increases the risk of sepsis.
* Acute kidney injury: The patient already has acute kidney injury, and the risk of further injury is high.
* Hyperglycemia: The patient has hyperglycemia, and the risk of further hyperglycemia is high.
* Pancytopenia: The patient has pancytopenia, and the risk of bleeding or infection is high.
* Acromegaly: The patient has acromegaly, and the risk of further complications, such as respiratory failure or cardiac arrhythmias, is high.
* Tumor lysis syndrome: The patient has a history of tumor lysis syndrome, and the risk of further episodes is high.

The patient requires close monitoring and management of his respiratory, cardiovascular, neurological, renal, infectious, metabolic, gastrointestinal, hematological, and endocrine conditions. The patient's care plan should include regular assessments of his respiratory status, blood glucose levels, and platelet count, as well as monitoring for signs of sepsis, acute kidney injury, and tumor lysis syndrome.

Based on the provided progress note, I have summarized the patient's current condition and potential medical complications:

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is a 40-year-old male with a recent diagnosis of Burkitt's lymphoma and acromegaly, currently intubated and mechanically ventilated in the ICU.
* He has a history of tumor lysis syndrome, which has resolved, but is at risk of recurrence.
* He is neutropenic (ANC < 500) and has a fever, with ongoing pneumonia and possible ARDS.
* He has a distended abdomen with hypoactive bowel sounds and no stool output for 6 days.
* He has hyperglycemia, which is being managed with an insulin drip.
* He has pancytopenia, with a precipitous drop in WBC count on day 1 of chemotherapy, and is at risk of bleeding and infection.
* He has tachycardia, which is likely physiologic due to infection, lymphoma, anemia, and high fever.
* He has joint pain, which is likely secondary to hypertrophic arthropathy from acromegaly.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he is at risk of further deterioration due to pneumonia, ARDS, and ventilator-associated complications.
* Infection: The patient's neutropenia and ongoing pneumonia make him at high risk of developing sepsis and multi-organ failure.
* Bleeding: The patient's pancytopenia and recent chemotherapy make him at risk of bleeding complications, including gastrointestinal bleeding and intracranial hemorrhage.
* Tumor lysis syndrome: The patient's recent resolution of tumor lysis syndrome makes him at risk of recurrence, which could lead to acute kidney injury, cardiac arrhythmias, and other complications.
* Acromegaly: The patient's new diagnosis of acromegaly makes him at risk of developing complications such as hyperglycemia, hypertension, and cardiac arrhythmias.
* Neurologic complications: The patient's recent diagnosis of lymphoma and acromegaly make him at risk of developing neurologic complications such as cranial nerve palsies, seizures, and cognitive impairment.

**Recommendations:**

* Continue close monitoring of the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilator settings as needed.
* Administer antibiotics and antifungals as prescribed to prevent and treat infections.
* Monitor the patient's blood counts and platelet levels closely to prevent bleeding complications.
* Continue to manage the patient's hyperglycemia with an insulin drip and monitor for signs of hypoglycemia.
* Consider consulting with an endocrinologist to optimize the patient's treatment plan for acromegaly.
* Continue to monitor the patient's joint pain and consider consulting with a rheumatologist for further management.
* Consider consulting with a neurologist to evaluate the patient's cranial nerve function and cognitive status.

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the following key points:

1. The patient is a 40-year-old male with a recent history of tumor lysis syndrome, Burkitt lymphoma, and acromegaly.
2. He is currently intubated in the ICU with respiratory failure, likely due to pneumonia and possible ARDS.
3. The patient has been receiving chemotherapy, including Hyper-CVAD, and has undergone multiple doses of rasburicase for tumor lysis syndrome.
4. He has developed pancytopenia, with a precipitous drop in WBC count on day 1 of chemotherapy, and is currently neutropenic.
5. The patient has a history of tachycardia, which is likely secondary to infection, lymphoma, anemia, and high cortisol levels.
6. He has distended abdomen with hypoactive bowel sounds, no stool for 6 days, and is receiving treatment for constipation.
7. The patient has hyperglycemia, likely due to dexamethasone, antibiotics, and acromegaly, and is receiving insulin therapy.
8. He has orchitis, with marked increase in testicular swelling, particularly on the left, thought to be secondary to malignant infiltration and generalized edema.
9. The patient has neurologic abnormalities, including Bell's palsy, loss of R facial sensation, weakness/decreased sensation of lower extremities, and cranial nerve palsies.
10. He has joint pain, likely secondary to hypertrophic arthropathy from acromegaly, and is receiving pain control with fentanyl.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and there is a risk of further deterioration, particularly if the pneumonia or ARDS worsens.
2. Sepsis: The patient's neutropenia and pancytopenia make him susceptible to infection, which could lead to sepsis.
3. Tumor lysis syndrome: The patient's tumor lysis syndrome is not fully resolved, and there is a risk of recurrence or worsening.
4. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia is likely to persist, and there is a risk of further complications, such as diabetic ketoacidosis or hyperosmolar non-ketotic coma.
5. Constipation: The patient's constipation is likely to persist, and there is a risk of further complications, such as bowel obstruction or perforation.
6. Orchitis: The patient's orchitis may worsen, leading to further testicular damage or infection.
7. Neurologic complications: The patient's neurologic abnormalities may worsen, leading to further cranial nerve palsies or spinal cord compression.
8. Joint pain: The patient's joint pain may worsen, leading to further disability and discomfort.

In light of these potential complications, I recommend the following:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust ventilator settings as necessary.
2. Continue to treat the patient's pancytopenia with blood product transfusions and neutropenic precautions.
3. Monitor the patient's tumor lysis syndrome labs closely and adjust treatment as necessary.
4. Continue to manage the patient's hyperglycemia with insulin therapy and close monitoring.
5. Continue to treat the patient's constipation with laxatives and stool softeners.
6. Monitor the patient's orchitis closely and consider further imaging or biopsy if necessary.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's neurologic status closely and consider further imaging or consultation with neurology if necessary.
8. Consider further consultation with endocrinology or rheumatology to manage the patient's acromegaly and joint pain.

Summary:

The patient is a 40-year-old male admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure due to pneumonia and possible ARDS. He has a history of Burkitt lymphoma and is currently receiving chemotherapy. He has developed acromegaly, a new presumptive diagnosis. The patient has been intubated since July 12 and has had two failed extubation attempts due to copious secretions. He is currently comfortable on CPAP/PSV with a FiO2 of 50% and PEEP of 10 cmH2O.

The patient has a number of ongoing medical issues, including:

* Pneumonia/infection: ongoing fevers with persistent infiltrates on CXR, with a recent drop in WBC count due to chemotherapy
* Tumor lysis syndrome: labs have stabilized, but the patient is still at risk for hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hyperuricemia
* Pancytopenia: the patient is neutropenic with a WBC count of 0.1, and has received 3 units of PRBCs and 1 unit of platelets
* Tachycardia: the patient has been consistently tachycardic, likely due to infection, lymphoma, anemia, and high cortisol levels
* Distended abdomen: the patient has abdominal distention with hypoactive bowel sounds, and has not had a bowel movement in 5 days
* Hyperglycemia: the patient's blood glucose levels have been in the 200-300 range, likely due to steroids, antibiotics, and acromegaly
* Joint pain: the patient has severe and diffuse arthralgias, likely due to hypertrophic arthropathy from acromegaly

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuing chemotherapy for Burkitt lymphoma
* Monitoring for and managing tumor lysis syndrome
* Managing pancytopenia with blood product transfusions and growth factor support
* Weaning sedation and adjusting ventilator settings as tolerated
* Monitoring for and managing respiratory failure
* Managing hyperglycemia with insulin therapy
* Managing joint pain with pain control medications
* Considering tracheostomy in the future when the patient's condition stabilizes

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: the patient is at risk for further respiratory decline due to ongoing pneumonia and possible ARDS
* Infection: the patient is at risk for further infection due to neutropenia and ongoing chemotherapy
* Tumor lysis syndrome: the patient is at risk for further hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hyperuricemia
* Pancytopenia: the patient is at risk for further bleeding and infection due to low platelet and WBC counts
* Tachycardia: the patient is at risk for further cardiac complications due to ongoing tachycardia
* Distended abdomen: the patient is at risk for further bowel obstruction and perforation due to ongoing distention
* Hyperglycemia: the patient is at risk for further complications due to ongoing hyperglycemia
* Joint pain: the patient is at risk for further joint damage due to ongoing arthralgias.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 69-inch tall individual weighing 88 kg, admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of respiratory failure, acute renal failure, and lymphoma. The patient's 24-hour events include blood cultures taken at 11:11 AM and 11:16 AM on [**2144-7-25**], as well as the initiation of intrathecal chemotherapy on [**7-26**].

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 38.2C (100.8F) at 12 AM, decreasing to 37.9C (100.2F) at 7:04 AM
* Heart rate: 98 bpm (84-117 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 107/52 mmHg (69-143/98 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 18 inspirations per minute (16-30 inspirations per minute)
* SpO2: 98%
* Weight: 88 kg (admission weight: 81.7 kg)

The patient's lab results include:

* White blood cell count: 19 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 7.3 g/dL
* Platelet count: 21 K/uL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 108 mg/dL
* Creatinine: 0.5 mg/dL
* Sodium: 130 mEq/L
* Potassium: 3.9 mEq/L
* Chloride: 30 mEq/L
* Calcium: 7.3 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.4 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 1.9 mg/dL
* Albumin: 2.8 g/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.7 mmol/L
* LDH: 1149 IU/L

The patient's physical examination is notable for impaired skin integrity, fever, hypotension, and respiratory failure. The patient's respiratory support includes mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure of 10 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen of 50%.

The patient's medical conditions include acute renal failure, lymphoma, and respiratory failure. The patient's ICU care includes nutrition via a NovaSource Renal (Full) solution at 20 mL/hour, as well as prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis, stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's conditions include:

* Sepsis due to the patient's fever and impaired skin integrity
* Acute kidney injury or worsening of acute renal failure due to hypotension and inadequate perfusion
* Respiratory failure exacerbation due to inadequate ventilation or worsening of underlying lung disease
* Infection or sepsis due to the patient's lymphoma and impaired immune function
* Bleeding or coagulopathy due to the patient's thrombocytopenia and platelet dysfunction

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, lab results, and respiratory support to prevent or manage these potential complications.

s lymphoma. New diagnosis of acromegaly, in ICU with

   presenting complaint was Bell
s Palsy, urinary retention, and lower
   extremity weakness.
   Respiratory failure: intubated since [**7-12**], s/p 2 failed extubations on
   [**7-15**] secondary to copious secretions and [**7-25**] due to work of breathing.

   Contributing factors to respiratory status include PNA and suspicion

   criteria starting [**7-18**]. However, compliance has remained normal so
   tolerating large tidal volumes on PSV.
   -Continue CMV/PS as per patient comfort, wean FiO2 and PEEP as

   -s/p 10day course Vanco (d/ced [**7-24**]) and 3 days meropenem (d/c
ed 3

Summary:

The patient is a 40-year-old male with a recent history of tumor lysis syndrome, started chemotherapy on July 21 for Burkitt's lymphoma. He is currently in the ICU with respiratory failure in the setting of pneumonia and possible ARDS. He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient has a number of ongoing medical issues, including:

* Pneumonia/Infection: ongoing fevers with persistent infiltrates on CXR, neutropenic fever today
* Tumor lysis syndrome: labs at admission were significant for elevated LDH, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hyperuricemia, which have since resolved to baseline
* Pancytopenia: platelets have been low throughout admission, precipitous drop in WBC on day 1 of chemo, Hct in low 20s throughout most of admission
* Hyperglycemia: blood glucose in the 200-300s starting July 23, largely due to dexamethasone, antibiotics in D50W, and acromegaly
* Acromegaly: new presumptive diagnosis based on clinical features, definitive work-up postponed until patient stabilized
* Orchitis: tender scrotal swelling on admission, scrotal US suggested epididymitis/orchitis, no clear masses
* Neurologic abnormalities: initial patient complaints included R Bell palsy, loss of R facial sensation, weakness/decreased sensation of lower extremities
* Joint pain: patient has severe and diffuse arthralgias, most likely secondary to hypertrophic arthropathy from acromegaly

Plan:

* Continue CMV/PS as per patient comfort, wean FiO2 and PEEP as tolerated
* Wean sedation with fentanyl/midazolam
* Patient autodiuresis to at least 100-200cc/hr, do not restart lasix gtt now in setting of metabolic alkalosis prior to extubation
* Follow ABGs when changes in ventilator settings or respiratory status (goal is pH >7.20, C02 <70)
* Daily CXR
* Patient will likely need tracheostomy in the future when condition has stabilized
* Continue oncological regimen as outlined by onc
* Consult rad-onc for possibility of radiation to skull in light of cranial nerve palsies
* Continue chemotherapeutic regimen as outlined by onc
* Pancytopenia: transfuse platelets and PRBC as needed, give neutropenic precautions
* Tachycardia: maximize comfort on ventilator, continue metoprolol 50mg Q6H
* Distended abdomen: continue colace, senna, dulcolax, and lactulose, try to wean fentanyl as possible
* Hyperglycemia: continue insulin drip with goal BG 100-150mg/dL, may be able to transition to less intensive insulin protocol when patient is no longer receiving steroids

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: ongoing respiratory failure in setting of pneumonia and possible ARDS
* Pneumonia/Infection: ongoing fevers with persistent infiltrates on CXR, neutropenic fever today
* Tumor lysis syndrome: labs at admission were significant for elevated LDH, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hyperuricemia, which have since resolved to baseline
* Pancytopenia: platelets have been low throughout admission, precipitous drop in WBC on day 1 of chemo, Hct in low 20s throughout most of admission
* Hyperglycemia: blood glucose in the 200-300s starting July 23, largely due to dexamethasone, antibiotics in D50W, and acromegaly
* Acromegaly: new presumptive diagnosis based on clinical features, definitive work-up postponed until patient stabilized
* Orchitis: tender scrotal swelling on admission, scrotal US suggested epididymitis/orchitis, no clear masses
* Neurologic abnormalities: initial patient complaints included R Bell palsy, loss of R facial sensation, weakness/decreased sensation of lower extremities
* Joint pain: patient has severe and diffuse arthralgias, most likely secondary to hypertrophic arthropathy from acromegaly

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 40-year-old male with a complex medical history, including ARDS, lymphoma, acromegaly, Bell's palsy, and tumor lysis syndrome. He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 50% and PSV of 8/8.

The patient has experienced several significant events, including reintubation, transfusions of platelets, and administration of various antibiotics. His laboratory results show a slightly decreased LDH, but his WBC and platelet counts are at nadir. He is neutropenic and febrile, with a temperature above 38.3C (100.9F).

The patient's respiratory status is concerning, with a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute and a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 222. His chest x-ray shows a bilateral infiltrate, consistent with ARDS. He requires close monitoring and potential tracheostomy.

The patient's cardiovascular status is also concerning, with a blood pressure of 107/52 mmHg and a central venous pressure of 29 cmH2O. His heart rhythm is sinus rhythm, but he has a history of hypertension.

The patient's renal function is compromised, with a creatinine level of 0.5 mg/dL and an estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) of 30 mL/min. He is receiving supportive care, including fluid management and electrolyte replacement.

The patient's nutritional status is compromised, with a caloric intake of 20 mL/hour and a requirement for total parenteral nutrition (TPN).

The patient's endocrine status is also concerning, with a history of acromegaly and macroadenoma. He is receiving insulin therapy for hyperglycemia and has a requirement for thyroid function tests.

The patient's code status is full code, and he is receiving prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is concerning, and he may require further respiratory support, including tracheostomy.
2. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's blood pressure is labile, and he may require further cardiovascular support, including vasopressors.
3. Renal failure: The patient's renal function is compromised, and he may require further renal support, including dialysis.
4. Infection: The patient is neutropenic and febrile, and he may be at risk for infection, including sepsis.
5. Tumor lysis syndrome: The patient has a history of lymphoma and tumor lysis syndrome, and he may require further management, including chemotherapy and supportive care.
6. Endocrine instability: The patient has a history of acromegaly and macroadenoma, and he may require further endocrine support, including thyroid function tests and hormone replacement therapy.
7. Nutritional compromise: The patient's nutritional status is compromised, and he may require further nutritional support, including TPN.

In summary, the patient is a critically ill individual with a complex medical history, requiring close monitoring and management to address his multiple medical complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 40-year-old male with a recent history of tumor lysis syndrome, Burkitt lymphoma, and acromegaly. He was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, pneumonia, and possible ARDS. He is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation. His vital signs are stable, but he is experiencing significant back and joint pain. He has a history of pancytopenia, neutropenic fever, and has received chemotherapy and antibiotics. He is at risk for further complications, including infection, bleeding, and tumor lysis syndrome.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he is at risk for further deterioration.
2. Infection: The patient has a history of pneumonia and is at risk for further infections, particularly with neutropenia.
3. Bleeding: The patient's platelet count is low, and he is at risk for bleeding.
4. Tumor lysis syndrome: The patient's tumor lysis syndrome is not fully resolved, and he is at risk for further complications.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood glucose levels are elevated, and he is at risk for further hyperglycemia.
6. Pancytopenia: The patient's pancytopenia is not fully resolved, and he is at risk for further complications.
7. ARDS: The patient's ARDS is not fully resolved, and he is at risk for further complications.
8. Malignant infiltration: The patient's lymphoma is spreading, and he is at risk for further malignant infiltration.
9. Hypercalcemia: The patient's calcium levels are elevated, and he is at risk for further hypercalcemia.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust his ventilator settings as needed.
2. Continue to administer antibiotics and antifungals to treat his pneumonia and possible ARDS.
3. Monitor the patient's platelet count and transfuse as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's blood glucose levels and adjust his insulin regimen as needed.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's pancytopenia and adjust his chemotherapy regimen as needed.
6. Consider repeating imaging studies to monitor the patient's tumor lysis syndrome and ARDS.
7. Consider consulting with a neurosurgeon to evaluate the patient's pituitary macroadenoma.
8. Consider consulting with an endocrinologist to evaluate the patient's acromegaly.
9. Consider consulting with a hematologist to evaluate the patient's pancytopenia and lymphoma.

Summary:

The patient is a 40-year-old male with a history of Burkitt's lymphoma, who was recently diagnosed with acromegaly and is currently in the ICU due to respiratory failure. He has been intubated since July 12th and has had two failed extubations. He is currently on a ventilator with a CPAP/PSV mode, with a FiO2 of 50% and a PEEP of 8 cmH2O. He has a history of tumor lysis syndrome, which has resolved, but his labs are currently stable.

The patient has a variety of medical conditions, including pneumonia, neutropenia, and pancytopenia. He is receiving chemotherapy for his lymphoma and has had three doses of rasburicase to treat tumor lysis syndrome. He is also receiving prophylaxis for fungal and viral infections.

The patient has a number of lab abnormalities, including elevated LDH, hyperkalemia, and hyperphosphatemia. His WBC count is low, and he is neutropenic. His platelet count is also low, and he has received a transfusion of platelets.

The patient has a number of medication allergies, including a reaction to vancomycin.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is at risk for further respiratory failure due to his underlying lung disease and the use of high-dose corticosteroids.
2. Pneumonia: The patient has a history of pneumonia and is at risk for further infection.
3. Neutropenia: The patient is neutropenic and at risk for infection.
4. Pancytopenia: The patient has a history of pancytopenia and is at risk for further bone marrow suppression.
5. Tumor lysis syndrome: The patient has a history of tumor lysis syndrome and is at risk for further episodes.
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient has a history of hyperglycemia and is at risk for further hyperglycemic episodes.
7. Hypotension: The patient is at risk for hypotension due to his underlying medical conditions and the use of vasodilators.
8. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has a history of cardiac arrhythmias and is at risk for further arrhythmias.
9. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding and is at risk for further bleeding.
10. Infection: The patient is at risk for infection due to his underlying medical conditions and the use of immunosuppressive medications.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's respiratory status will be closely monitored, and he will be weaned off the ventilator as tolerated. He will continue to receive prophylaxis for fungal and viral infections. His chemotherapy regimen will be continued as outlined by his oncologist. His lab abnormalities will be closely monitored, and he will receive further treatment as needed. His medication allergies will be taken into consideration when selecting medications. His social situation will be closely monitored, and he will be encouraged to communicate with his family and healthcare providers.

   40M with recent h/o tumor lysis syndrome, started chemotherapy on [**7-21**]
   for Burkitt
s lymphoma. New diagnosis of acromegaly, in ICU with
   respiratory failure in setting of pneumonia, possible ARDS. Original
   presenting complaint was Bell
s Palsy, urinary retention, and lower
   extremity weakness.
   Respiratory failure: intubated since [**7-12**], s/p 2 failed extubations on
   [**7-15**] secondary to copious secretions and [**7-25**] due to work of breathing.
   Intermittent dysynchrony with vent, currently comfortable on AC.
   Contributing factors to respiratory status include PNA and suspicion
   for infiltrative malignant process on CT, as well as meeting ARDS
   criteria starting [**7-18**]. However, compliance has remained normal so
   tolerating large tidal volumes on PSV.
   -Continue CMV/PS as per patient comfort, wean FiO2 and PEEP as
   tolerated
   -Wean sedation with fentanyl/midazolam
   -Continue autodiuresis to at least 100-200cc/hr. Start lasix gtt if
   needed but monitor metabolic alkalosis
   -follow ABGs when changes in ventilator settings or respiratory status
   (Goal is ph>7.20, C02<70)
   -Daily CXR
   -patient will likely need tracheostomy. Contact IP tomorrow. Call HCP
   today to set up a meeting to discuss that early this week.
   Pneumonia/Infection: ongoing fevers with persistent infiltrates at R
   base on CXR. WBC elevated on [**7-18**], now precipitously dropped in setting
   of chemotherapy. Patient is now neutropenic (ANC<<500)
   -s/p 10day course Vanco (d/ced [**7-24**]) and 3 days meropenem (d/c
ed 3
   [**7-24**]), 2 dys flaygl (d/ced [**7-25**])
   -cipro (day 8,start [**7-19**])
   -cefepime 2gm IV q8h (day 4)
   -doxycycline 100mg [**Hospital1 **] for mycoplasma coverage (day 5)
   -Start vanco again today for fever, neutropenia.
   -Sputum cx from [**7-23**] positive for coag+ staph, repeat sputum cx if
   possible
   -prophylaxis with fluconazole (day 6, start [**7-21**]), acyclovir (day 5),
   atovaquone for PCP [**Name Initial (PRE) 1694**] (day 4: d/ced Bactrim)
   -check G6PD if negative, will switch atovaquone to dapsone for better
   efficacy
   -urine cx for Mycoplasma hominsis negative
   -f/u final BAL results, blood cx, CSF fungal, AFB, and viral cx, CSF
   EBV PCR, serum EBV, CMV, HHV-6 PCR, and galactomannan and B-glucan
   Tumor lysis syndrome: Labs at admission were significant for elevated
   LDH, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia which all resolved
   to baseline. Patient s/p 3 doses rasburicase, last dose 7/10. Tumor
   lysis labs started to rise again on [**7-21**]. Today they are relatively
   stable.
   -f/u tumor lysis labs Q8H
   -keep UOP at least 100cc/hr; currently autodiuresing
   -continue allopurinol
   -increase phos in tube feeds in setting of phos back to normal/low
   today
   -renal following in case of tumor lysis induced ATN again. Cre
   currently stable.
   Burkitt
s lymphoma: CT shows diffuse evidence of malignancy - c/w
   lymphangitic spread of diffuse malignant process, thickening in
   stomach, ureters. Bone marrow bx c/w Burkitt
s lymphoma. Hyper-CVAD
   started on [**7-21**]. now s/p [**3-20**] doses cyclophosphamide, cytarabine
   intrathecal x 1, s/p vincristine and doxorubicin [**7-23**], s/p intrathecal
   methotrexate
   -f/u onc recs
   -IT chemo today, give platelets first
   - continue chemotherapeutic regimen as outlined by onc
   -gadolinium-enhanced head MRI when patient stabilized to investigate
   extent of lymphoma and possible need for radiation to head
   Pancytopenia: Platelets following throughout this admission,
   precipitous drop in WBC on day 1 of chemo, Hct in low 20s throughout
   most of admission.  Neutropenic fever today
   -s/p 1 units of PRBC over last 24 hours
   -transfuse again if needed (Hct<21)
   -give platelets if needed (<15)
   -CBC Q8H
   -neupogen started yesterday
   -neutropenic precautions
   Tachycardia: Consistently tachycardic to 110s/120s. TSH WNL, TTE showed
   normal EF and no evidence of heart failure. Repeat EKGs have shown
   frequent PVCs, no signs of myocardial ischemia. Likely physiologic
   tachycardia secondary to infection, lymphoma, anemia, high [**Hospital1 **].
   -maximize comfort on ventilator
   -EKG on [**7-23**] at baseline
   -continue metoprolol
   Distended abdomen: abdominal distention is stable with hypoactive bowel
   sounds. No stool for 6 days.
   -Colace, senna, dulcolax, and lactulose
   -s/p methylnaltrexone x1 and PO narcan.
   -Try to wean fentanyl as possible
   -restart tube feeds with free water flushes to improve hypernatremia
   -repeat LFTs
   -KUB
   Hyperglycemia: blood glucose in the 200- 300s starting [**7-23**] largely due
   to the dexamethasone, antibiotics in D50W and acromegaly.
   -started insulin drip with goal BG 100-150mg/dL
   -may be able to transition to less intensive insulin protocol when
   patient is no longer receiving steriods
   Social:
   -in touch with family as well as HCP [**Name (NI) 1068**] (friend), will contact today
   regarding possibility of trach.
   The following issues are not acute or active but left on the note to be
   followed up on when Mr. [**Known lastname 7019**] is awake and stabilized:
   Acromegaly: New presumptive diagnosis based on clinical features.
   Definitive work-up postponed until patient stabilized.
   -f/u with endocrine
   -f/u endocrine labs (IGFBP, Vit D)
   -ophtho consult for visual fields when patient extubated/alert
   Orchitis:  Tender scrotal swelling on admission, scrotal US suggested
   epididymitis/orchitis. No clear masses. G&C swab negative. Exam
   starting [**7-17**] shows marked increase in testicular swelling, particularly
   on the left. Thought to be secondary to malignant infiltration and
   generalized edema.
   -f/u when patient stabilized, likely due to lymphoma
   Neurologic abnormalities: Initial patient complaints included R Bell
   palsy, loss of R facial sensation, weakness/decreased sensation of
   lower extremities. MRI T-spine at OSH showed epidural enhancement of
   thoracic spine; MRI head showed pituitary macroadenoma.
   -neurosurgery has low suspicion for cord compression and repeat MRI of
   spine not necessary.
   -Repeat MRI of pituitary eventually needed although in light of recent
   ARF, this is not a priority and can wait until patient stabilized.
   -better neuro exam as we wean sedation, particularly focused on cranial
   nerve
s V and VII and lower extremity sensation/motor
   Joint pain: Patient has severe and diffuse arthralgias, most likely
   secondary to hypertrophic arthropathy from acromegaly.
   -avoiding NSAIDs
   -tylenol when awake
   -continue pain control with fentanyl

Summary:

The patient, a 40-year-old male, is admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, sepsis, and possible ARDS. He has a history of Burkitt's lymphoma, tumor lysis syndrome, and acromegaly. He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. His laboratory results show elevated WBC count, neutropenia, and hyperglycemia. He is receiving chemotherapy and antibiotics, and his condition is unstable.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, leading to further complications such as respiratory acidosis, hypoxia, and cardiac arrest.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may progress, leading to organ dysfunction, septic shock, and death.
3. ARDS: The patient's ARDS may worsen, leading to further respiratory failure and multi-organ dysfunction.
4. Tumor lysis syndrome: The patient's tumor lysis syndrome may recur, leading to further complications such as kidney injury, cardiac arrhythmias, and death.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia may worsen, leading to further complications such as diabetic ketoacidosis, hyperosmolar non-ketotic coma, and death.
6. Neutropenic fever: The patient's neutropenic fever may progress, leading to further complications such as sepsis, septic shock, and death.
7. Pancytopenia: The patient's pancytopenia may worsen, leading to further complications such as bleeding, infection, and death.
8. Acromegaly: The patient's acromegaly may worsen, leading to further complications such as respiratory failure, cardiac failure, and death.
9. Malignant infiltration: The patient's malignant infiltration may worsen, leading to further complications such as organ dysfunction, sepsis, and death.

ICU Care:

The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation, antibiotics, and chemotherapy. His laboratory results are being closely monitored, and he is receiving prophylactic medications for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP. His family has been informed of the possibility of tracheostomy, and the patient's code status is full code.

   Assessment and Plan
   40M with recent h/o tumor lysis syndrome, started chemotherapy on [**7-21**]
   for Burkitt
s lymphoma. New diagnosis of acromegaly, in ICU with
   respiratory failure in setting of pneumonia, possible ARDS. Original
   presenting complaint was Bell
s Palsy, urinary retention, and lower
   extremity weakness.
   Respiratory failure: intubated since [**7-12**], s/p 2 failed extubations on
   [**7-15**] secondary to copious secretions and [**7-25**] due to work of breathing.
   Intermittent dysynchrony with vent, currently comfortable on AC.
   Contributing factors to respiratory status include PNA and suspicion
   for infiltrative malignant process on CT, as well as meeting ARDS
   criteria starting [**7-18**]. However, compliance has remained normal so
   tolerating large tidal volumes on PSV.
   -CXR this morning worse and patient reporting subjective dyspnea.
   Possibly related to IVF overload.
   -Increase PEEP to 10 for increased comfort, continue CMV on [**8-24**]
   changing for patient comfort. Consider weaning FiO2 and PEEP as
   tolerated but this is not a priority as patient has failed 2
   extubations and we are not planning imminent extubation in his state of
   critical illness, fever, immunocompromise, and chemotherapy.
   -Keep sedation off as long as patient as comfortable with bolus IV
   fentanyl for pain control.
   -Continue autodiuresis to at least 100-200cc/hr. Start lasix gtt.
   -monitor mixed alkalosis with ABG in hopes increased PEEP will help.
   Start acetazolamide and give K+ to help with metabolic portion of
   alkalosis
   -follow ABGs when changes in ventilator settings or respiratory status
   (Goal is ph>7.20, C02<70)
   -Daily CXR
   -patient will likely need tracheostomy, which was addressed with HCP
   and family over the weekend and they support it if needed. He is not a
   candidate now given fevers, low platelets, but keep in mind as a goal
   toward the end of the week.
   Pneumonia/Infection: ongoing fevers with persistent infiltrates at R
   base on CXR. WBC elevated on [**7-18**], now precipitously dropped in setting
   of chemotherapy. Patient is now neutropenic (ANC<<500).
   -s/p 10day course Vanco (d/ced [**7-24**]) and 3 days meropenem (d/c
ed 3
   [**7-24**]), 2 dys flaygl (d/ced [**7-25**])
   -Pneumonia, presumed mycoplasma hominis: doxycycline 100mg [**Hospital1 **] (day 6)
   and cipro (day 9,start [**7-19**]).
   -Neutropenic, febrile: vanco started again (day 2); cefepime 2gm IV q8h
   (day 5)
   -Sputum cx from [**7-23**] positive for coag+ staph, repeat sputum pending,
   covered by vanc
   -A-line grew gram positive cocci in clusters. Covered with vanc
   -resite A-line, pull IJ for line holiday with onc permission
   -prophylaxis with fluconazole (day 7, start [**7-21**]), acyclovir (day 6),
   atovaquone for PCP [**Name Initial (PRE) 1694**] (day 5: d/ced Bactrim)
   -check G6PD if negative, will switch atovaquone to dapsone for better
   efficacy
   -f/u final BAL results, blood cx, CSF fungal, AFB, and viral cx, CSF
   EBV PCR, serum EBV, CMV, HHV-6 PCR, and galactomannan and B-glucan
   Tumor lysis syndrome: Labs at admission were significant for elevated
   LDH, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia which all resolved
   to baseline. Patient s/p 3 doses rasburicase, last dose 7/10. Tumor
   lysis labs started to rise again on [**7-21**]. Today they are relatively
   stable.
   -f/u tumor lysis labs Q8H
   -keep UOP at least 100cc/hr; currently autodiuresing. Start lasix gtt
   again.
   -continue allopurinol
   -phos low/normal, monitor as return to normal tube feeds
   -replete K as needed
   Burkitt
s lymphoma: CT shows diffuse evidence of malignancy - c/w
   lymphangitic spread of diffuse malignant process, thickening in
   stomach, ureters. Bone marrow bx c/w Burkitt
s lymphoma. Hyper-CVAD
   started on [**7-21**]. now s/p [**3-20**] doses cyclophosphamide, cytarabine
   intrathecal x 1, s/p vincristine and doxorubicin [**7-23**], s/p intrathecal
   methotrexate
   -continue chemotherapeutic regimen as outlined by onc. Request detailed
   plan for chemo over next few weeks to plan accordingly with access,
   dexamethasone, LPs, etc.
   -touch base with onc regarding back pain and if is expected in setting
   of IT MTX yesterday
   -gadolinium-enhanced head MRI when patient stabilized to investigate
   extent of lymphoma and possible need for radiation to head. This is
   only necessary if medical treatment fails and is not an urgent issue.
   Pancytopenia: Platelets following throughout this admission,
   precipitous drop in WBC on day 1 of chemo, Hct in low 20s throughout
   most of admission.  Neutropenic fever today
   -s/p 1 units of PRBC over last 24 hours
   -transfuse again if needed (Hct<21)
   -give platelets if needed (<15)
   -CBC Q8H
   -neupogen day 3 (hold day 10 and 11, [**7-30**] and [**7-31**])
   -DIC labs Q24H, per onc
   -neutropenic precautions
   Tachycardia: Consistently tachycardic to 110s/120s. TSH WNL, TTE showed
   normal EF and no evidence of heart failure. Repeat EKGs have shown
   frequent PVCs, no signs of myocardial ischemia. Likely physiologic
   tachycardia secondary to infection, lymphoma, anemia, high [**Hospital1 **].
   -maximize comfort on ventilator
   -EKG on [**7-23**] at baseline
   -continue metoprolol
   Distended abdomen: abdominal distention is stable with hypoactive bowel
   sounds. No stool for 7 days but now passing gas.
   -Colace, senna, dulcolax, and lactulose
   - continue PO narcan but monitor for increased pain
   -Try to wean fentanyl as possible
   -tube feeds with free water flushes to improve hypernatremia
   -repeat LFTs normal
   -KUB showed large amount of stool, likely impaction
   Hyperglycemia: blood glucose in the 200- 300s starting [**7-23**] largely due
   to the dexamethasone, antibiotics in D5W and acromegaly.
   -on ISS with goal BG 100-150mg/dL. Switch to drip if needed
   Pain control: significant back and joint pain today in setting of
   sedation weaned.
   -bolus fentanyl as needed
   Social:
   -in touch with family as well as HCP [**Name (NI) 1068**] (friend). They support a
   trach if that becomes necessary/possible.
   -social work consult
   The following issues are not acute or active but left on the note to be
   followed up on when Mr. [**Known lastname 7019**] is awake and stabilized:
   Acromegaly: New presumptive diagnosis based on clinical features.
   Definitive work-up postponed until patient stabilized.
   -f/u with endocrine
   -f/u endocrine labs (IGFBP, Vit D)
   -ophtho consult for visual fields when patient extubated/alert
   Orchitis:  Tender scrotal swelling on admission, scrotal US suggested
   epididymitis/orchitis. No clear masses. G&C swab negative. Exam
   starting [**7-17**] shows marked increase in testicular swelling, particularly
   on the left. Thought to be secondary to malignant infiltration and
   generalized edema.
   -f/u when patient stabilized, likely due to lymphoma
   Neurologic abnormalities: Initial patient complaints included R Bell
   palsy, loss of R facial sensation, weakness/decreased sensation of
   lower extremities. MRI T-spine at OSH showed epidural enhancement of

   -neurosurgery has low suspicion for cord compression and repeat MRI of

   -Repeat MRI of pituitary eventually needed although in light of recent

   -better neuro exam as we wean sedation, particularly focused on cranial

s V and VII and lower extremity sensation/motor
   Joint pain: Patient has severe and diffuse arthralgias, most likely
